Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions US-China: Collaborative Research: How historical constraints, local adaptation, and species interactions shape biodiversity across an ancient floristic disjunction
Award.AbstractNarration:
Biodiversity is multidimensional, composed of genetic, phenotypic, ecological, and geographic variation within and among species. Understanding the sources and patterns of Earth's biodiversity will lead to a better understanding of our planet's ecosystems and new strategies on how to conserve them. Within forests, plants grow in association with soil bacteria and fungi, but little is known about how these associations vary within and among forests, or how these interactions maintain or generate biodiversity. The forests of eastern Asia and eastern North America were anciently connected and have a shared evolutionary and ecological history; they therefore offer a unique opportunity to study the drivers of biodiversity across geographical space and through evolutionary time. This collaborative project among researchers at the University of Florida, North Carolina State University, Chicago University and colleagues at the Chinese Academy of Sciences and Zhejiang University investigates how the associations among plant, fungal and soil bacteria shape biodiversity through space and time. The research team has developed an extensive education and training program for undergraduates, graduate students and post-doctoral researchers comprising both field and lab components. Training will also include a cyber-enabled course for Chinese and US participants that will promote international scientific collaborations. This research will also contribute valuable information to improve global climate change models that inform national and international climate and energy policies.

This multidisciplinary project integrates phylogenomics, biogeography, and plant and microbial evolution and ecology to address novel questions on the origins and maintenance of biodiversity. The research team will reconstruct phylogenies using next-generation DNA sequencing methods to provide a robust framework for improved dating and biogeographic analyses. Comparative community phylogenetic analyses at six forest sites in eastern North America and four sites in China will evaluate spatial patterns of phylogenetic diversity within and between continents. Exploration of fungal and soil bacteria taxic and functional diversity will yield new understanding of their biodiversity and interactions with plants. Ecosystem function, inferred from analysis of plant functional traits and remotely sensed canopy properties, will be computed at all sites and linked to analyses of fungal and soil bacteria function. Innovative applications of phylogenetic and comparative methodologies will lead to new discoveries in phylogenetic and functional diversity of plants, soil bacteria and fungi at community and regional scales. Integration of historical connections, current patterns, and future species distribution models will lead to more holistic views of the drivers of biodiversity and will enable future hypothesis-driven research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report 

Microbial genomic DNA from 868 leaf samples, representing 31 different tree genera, were collected at the Talladega (TALL), Ordway (OSBS), Coweeta (CWHL), Harvard Forest (HF), Mountain Lake (MLBS), and White Mountain (WMNF) sites. The DNA samples were sent to Argonne for PCR amplification, sequence preparation, sequencing, and analysis. All 868 samples were PCR amplified and multiplexed using Golay barcoded primers. The PCR amplification was carried out using the 515f (GTGYCAGCMGCCGCGGTAA) and 806r (GGACTACNVGGGTWTCTAAT) universal bacterial/archaeal primer set with mPNA and pPNA blockers for host mitochondria and chloroplasts, respectively. The thermocycler started at 94°C for 3 minutes, then completed 35 cycles of 94°C for 45 seconds, 50°C for 60 seconds, and 72°C for 90 seconds with a final step of 72°C for 10 minutes. Samples were then prepared for an Illumina MiSeq 151x151bp run and submitted for sequencing to the Argonne-UChicago sequencing core. All sequencing data has been generated and analyzed.

We wanted to determine whether the microbial communities associated with leaves of different tree species was predictive of those tree species, suggesting tree-species-specific influences on leaf microbial biodiversity and assemblage. The association between leaf functional traits and microbial diversity as well as how these traits drove the variations of microbial assemblage were also characterized. Comparison between different sites was also proposed in order to determine if differences associated with the trees were conserved between sites.

By analyzing the sequencing data from 4 sites (MLBS, WMNF, CWHL and HF), we found that the leaf bacterial diversity significantly varied among different tree families and genera (Fig. 1). Interestingly, the bacterial diversity was highest in MLBS, while WMNF was still significantly higher compared to the remaining two sites. This could be due to different tree genera being distributed throughout different sites. The microbial assemblage was significantly different in samples associated with different tree genera. The most abundant phyla include Proteobacteria, Firmicutes, Bacteroidetes, and Actinobacteria, while the taxa Massilia, Enterococcus, Sphingomonas, Methylobacterium, Hymenobacter, and Candidatus Uzinura were the most dominant genera. By calculating the beta-diversity based on the Bray-Curtis distance, the leaf samples clustered into three groups. The samples associated with tree genus Sassafras was separate from the other samples, and this separation was related to the Actinobacteria. The samples associated with tree genera Acer, Magnolia, and Nyssa grouped together, which was mainly driven by the bacterial phyla Planctomycetes, Firmicutes, and Verrucomicrobia, while the remaining samples grouped together as dictated by bacterial phyla Cyanobacteria, Bacteroidetes, and Proteobacteria. Also, we found that the microbial community composition significantly differed between MLBS and the other sites, which can also be attributed to the difference in composition of tree species.

These results suggest a tree-species-specific impact on the microbial diversity and community assemblage. Further, this supports the hypothesis that the host genotype, or identity, is the major influence on determining the endophyte microbial colonization. The site-specific pattern of taxa distribution reveals the recruitment of microbes from the soil. Along with the leaf trait data for the US sites, our Chinese collaborators have generated data from the leaves from the Chinese sites, and leaf trait data have been shown to influence microbial composition on leaves. The community patterns are shaped by leaf chemistry across the evolutionary transition. We see site-specific differences due to recruitment from the soil, but also taxa that are uniquely adapted to different species, as specific tree-phylogeny scales. Moreover, the microbial metabolisms based on the 16S rRNA sequencing data suggest specific functional potentials associated with the tree species and sampling locations.
